PROTMETHNAME: Viable Salmonid Population Abundance and Productivity Field and Analysis Methods for Natural Origin Steelhead populations in the Mid-Columbia Distinct Population Segment of Northeast-Central Oregon from 1967 to 2014
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Multi Pass GRTS SGS Redd Expansion
COMMENTS: GRTS spawning ground surveys in the IMW area, expanded to the total population area.  Hatchery proportions calculated using 5-year running totals (i.e. each year bracketed by two years on either side when data available), from trapping and seining activities in the Upper John Day Basin and live and dead fish observed during GRTS and Index surveys on the upper John Day Basin. Age proportions beginning in 2007 are derived from juveniles aged using scales of spring migrants captured in rotary screw traps and PIT tag data from adults captured at Columbia River Dams.
MEASURELOCATION: Redd count data can be found at www.streamnet.org/data
METACOMMENTS: ODFW reserves the right to review and revise data as needed. Consult the contact person for metric, and measure data.

POPFITNOTES: It is Important to Note that the Number provided for NOSA includes "stray" wild origin fish from other basins, which have also been included in the Total and pHOS calculations.  Estimate for wild "stray" in 2008 is 217 fish..These estimates are for the mainstem Tucannon River, and tributaries upstream of the mouth.  The ICTRT also included small streams that empty directly into the Snake River (Alkali Flat, Penwawa, Deadman, Meadow) as part of the Tucannon River steelhead population. The number of wild steelhead in these small streams are still being evaluated, and the estimates included here are not final values.
CONTACTAGENCY: Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife
PROTMETHDOCUMENTATION: BPA Annual Report provides brief desciption/results, but a formal protocol is currently being drafted

PROTMETHNAME: Viable Salmonid Population Abundance and Productivity Field and Analysis Methods for Natural Origin Steelhead populations in the Mid-Columbia Distinct Population Segment of Northeast-Central Oregon from 1967 to 2014
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Single Pass Index SGS Redd Expansion
COMMENTS: Hatchery proportions calculated using 5-year running totals (i.e. each year bracketed by two years on either side when data available), from live and dead fish observed during Index surveys on the entire John Day Basin. Age proportions derived from scale analysis of primarily angler caught adults during the 1980's.
MEASURELOCATION: Redd count data for Index surveys can be found at www.streamnet.org/data
METACOMMENTS: ODFW reserves the right to review and revise data as needed. Consult the contact person for metric, and measure data.

METHODADJUSTMENTS: Single Pass Index SGS Redd Expansion

PROTMETHNAME: Viable Salmonid Population Abundance and Productivity Field and Analysis Methods for Natural Origin summer Steelhead populations in the Snake River Summer Steelhead DPS of Northeast Oregon from 1950-2015
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Single Pass Index SGS Redd Expansion
COMMENTS: pHOS assumed 0. Age proportion is mean proportion at age from sex-length and scale age data collected from 1999-2004 on steelhead captured at three CTUIR weirs in the Grande Ronde River basin.
MEASURELOCATION: Redd count data can be found at www.streamnet.org/data

POPFITNOTES: It is Important to Note that the Number provided for NOSA includes "stray" wild origin fish from other basins, which have also been included in the Total and pHOS calculations.  Estimate for wild "stray" in 2011 is 200 fish..These estimates are for the mainstem Tucannon River, and tributaries upstream of the mouth.  The ICTRT also included small streams that empty directly into the Snake River (Alkali Flat, Penwawa, Deadman, Meadow) as part of the Tucannon River steelhead population.  The number of wild steelhead in these small streams are still being evaluated, and the estimates included here are not final values.

PROTMETHDOCUMENTATION: BPA Annual Report provides brief desciption/results, but a formal protocol is currently being drafted

POPFITNOTES: It is Important to  Note that the Number provided for NOSA includes "stray" wild origin fish from other basins, which have also been included in the Total and pHOS calculations.  Estimate for wild "stray" in 2013 is 220 fish..These estimates are for the mainstem Tucannon River, and tributaries upstream of the mouth.  The ICTRT also included small streams that empty directly into the Snake River (Alkali Flat, Penwawa, Deadman, Meadow) as part of the Tucannon River steelhead population.  The number of wild steelhead in these small streams is being evaluated but incomplete at this time, so have not been included here.
CONTACTAGENCY: Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife
PROTMETHDOCUMENTATION: BPA Annual Report provides brief desciption/results, but a formal protocol is currently being drafted

COMMENTS: pHOS calculated using 5-year running totals (i.e. each year bracketed by two years on either side when data available), from live and dead fish observed during Index surveys on the entire John Day Basin. Age proportions derived from juveniles aged using scales of spring migrants captured in rotary screw traps and PIT tag data from adults captured at Columbia River
MEASURELOCATION: Redd count data for Index surveys can be found at www.streamnet.org/data
METACOMMENTS: ODFW reserves the right to review and revise data as needed. Consult the contact person for metric, and measure data.

PROTMETHNAME: Viable Salmonid Population Abundance and Productivity Field and Analysis Methods for Natural Origin Steelhead populations in the Mid-Columbia Distinct Population Segment of Northeast-Central Oregon from 1967 to 2014
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Multi Pass Stratified Random SGS Redd Expantion
COMMENTS: No spawning ground observations were made in 2006 due to poor water conditions.  An estimate of the spawner abundance for 2006 is made by reconstructing the unknown 3 - 6 yr old cohorts from brood years 2000 - 2003 based on the average proportion at age by brood year for years with observations. pHOS assumed zero - no ability to collect hatchery observations. Age structure derived from NO winter steelhead in the Hood River (Reagan and Olsen 2008).
MEASURELOCATION: Redd count data can be found at www.streamnet.org/data
METACOMMENTS: ODFW reserves the right to review and revise data as needed. Consult the contact person for metric, and measure data.

POPFITNOTES: It is Important to Note that the Number provided for NOSA includes "stray" wild origin fish from other basins, which have also been included in the Total and pHOS calculations.  Estimate for wild "stray" in 2015 is 200 fish..These estimates are for the mainstem Tucannon River, and tributaries upstream of the mouth.  The ICTRT also included small streams that empty directly into the Snake River (Alkali Flat, Penwawa, Deadman, Meadow) as part of the Tucannon River steelhead population.  The number of wild steelhead in these small streams is being evaluated but incomplete at this time, so have not been included here.
CONTACTAGENCY: Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife
PROTMETHDOCUMENTATION: BPA Annual Report provides brief desciption/results, but a formal protocol is currently being drafted

POPFITNOTES: It is Important to  Note that the Number provided for NOSA includes "stray" wild origin fish from other basins which have also been included in the Total and pHOS calculations.  Estimate for wild "stray" in 2017 is 80 fish..These estimates are for the mainstem Tucannon River, and tributaries upstream of the mouth.  The ICTRT also included small streams that empty directly into the Snake River (Alkali Flat, Penwawa, Deadman, Meadow) as part of the Tucannon River steelhead population.  The number of wild steelhead in these small streams are still being evaluated, and the estimates included here are not final values.
CONTACTAGENCY: Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife
PROTMETHDOCUMENTATION: BPA Annual Report provides brief desciption/results, but a formal protocol is currently being drafted
COMMENTS: Number provided for NOSA includes "stray" wild origin fish from other basins, which have also been included in the Total and pHOS calculations.  Estimate for wild "stray" in 2016 is 80 fish.

POPFITNOTES: It is Important to Note that the Number provided for NOSA includes "stray" wild origin fish from other basins which have also been included in the Total and pHOS calculations.  Estimate for wild "stray" in 2018 is 40 fish..These estimates are for the mainstem Tucannon River, and tributaries upstream of the mouth.  The ICTRT also included small streams that empty directly into the Snake River (Alkali Flat, Penwawa, Deadman, Meadow) as part of the Tucannon River steelhead population.  The number of wild steelhead in these small streams are still being evaluated, and the estimates included here are not final values.
CONTACTAGENCY: Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife
PROTMETHDOCUMENTATION: BPA Annual Report provides brief desciption/results, but a formal protocol is currently being drafted
COMMENTS: Number provided for NOSA includes "stray" wild origin fish from other basins, which have also been included in the Total and pHOS calculations.  Estimate for wild "stray" in 2017 is 40 fish.

METHODADJUSTMENTS: Multi Pass GRTS SGS Redd Expansion
COMMENTS: GRTS spawning ground surveys in the IMW area, expanded to the total population area.  Hatchery proportions calculated using 5-year running totals (i.e. each year bracketed by two years on either side when data available), from trapping and seining activities in the Upper John Day Basin and live and dead fish observed during GRTS and Index surveys on the upper John Day Basin. Age proportions beginning in 2007 are derived from juveniles aged using scales of spring migrants captured in rotary screw traps and PIT tag data from adults captured at Columbia River Dams.
MEASURELOCATION: Redd count data can be found at www.streamnet.org/data
METACOMMENTS: ODFW reserves the right to review and revise data as needed. Consult the contact person for metric, and measure data.

PROTMETHNAME: Viable Salmonid Population Abundance and Productivity Field and Analysis Methods for Natural Origin Steelhead populations in the Mid-Columbia Distinct Population Segment of Northeast-Central Oregon from 1967 to 2014
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Single Pass Index SGS Redd Expansion
COMMENTS: pHOS calculated using 5-year running totals (i.e. each year bracketed by two years on either side when data available), from live and dead fish observed during Index surveys on the entire John Day Basin. Age proportions derived from juveniles aged using scales of spring migrants captured in rotary screw traps and PIT tag data from adults captured at Columbia River Dams.
MEASURELOCATION: Redd count data for Index surveys can be found at www.streamnet.org/data
METACOMMENTS: ODFW reserves the right to review and revise data as needed. Consult the contact person for metric, and measure data.

PROTMETHNAME: Viable Salmonid Population Abundance and Productivity Field and Analysis Methods for Natural Origin summer Steelhead populations in the Snake River Summer Steelhead DPS of Northeast Oregon from 1950-2015
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Single Pass Index SGS Redd Expansion
COMMENTS: pHOS assumed 0. Age proportion is mean proportion at age from sex-length and scale age data collected from 1999-2004 on steelhead captured at three CTUIR weirs
MEASURELOCATION: Redd count data can be found at www.streamnet.org/data
METACOMMENTS: ODFW reserves the right to review and revise data as needed. Consult the contact person for metric, and measure data.

PROTMETHNAME: Viable Salmonid Population Abundance and Productivity Field and Analysis Methods for Natural Origin Steelhead populations in the Mid-Columbia Distinct Population Segment of Northeast-Central Oregon from 1967 to 2014
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Multi Pass Stratified Random SGS Redd Expantion
COMMENTS: No spawning ground obervations were made in 2009 due to poor water conditions.   An estimate of the spawner abundance for 2009 is made by reconstructing the unknown 3 - 6 yr old cohorts from brood years 2003 - 2006 based on the average proportion at age by brood year for years with observations. pHOS assumed zero - no ability to collect hatchery observations. Age structure derived from NO winter steelhead in the Hood River (Reagan and Olsen 2008).
MEASURELOCATION: Redd count data can be found at www.streamnet.org/data
METACOMMENTS: ODFW reserves the right to review and revise data as needed. Consult the contact person for metric, and measure data.

PROTMETHNAME: chinook-dams-lc-adult-abundance.Design_6.doc, chinook-dams-lc-hatchery_proportion.Design_5.doc
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Prior to 2002 hatchery fish could not be distinguished from natural origin fish and were all passed above North Fork Dam.  The average of the hatchery proportion observed arriving at the dam in 2002 and 2003 has been applied to counts from 1974 to 2001. After 2002 marked fish were excluded above the dam, however a small proportion of hatchery fish are missed during marking. This proportion is determined by analyzing otolith marks from carcasses observed on the spawning grounds.
COMMENTS: Count at North Fork Dam / 0.78 and adjusted for unmarked hatchery-origin fish.  Includes Fall Creek.
METACOMMENTS: Dam counts are located at the URL indicated in the MeasureLocation field. Consult the contact person for data regarding the remaining measures.

PROTMETHNAME: Lower Columbia River Conservation and Recovery Plan for Oregon Populations of Salmon and Steelhead, chinook-dams-lc-adult-abundance.Design_6.doc, chinook-dams-lc-hatchery_proportion.Design_5.doc
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Prior to 2002 hatchery fish could not be distinguished from natural origin fish and were all passed above North Fork Dam.  The average of the hatchery proportion observed arriving at the dam in 2002 and 2003 has been applied to counts from 1974 to 2001. After 2002 marked fish were excluded above the dam, however a small proportion of hatchery fish are missed during marking. This proportion is determined by analyzing otolith marks from carcasses observed on the spawning grounds.
COMMENTS: Count at North Fork Dam / 0.78.  There were no measurements of hatchery/wild proportions until 2002.

PROTMETHNAME: Lower Columbia River Conservation and Recovery Plan for Oregon Populations of Salmon and Steelhead, chinook-dams-lc-adult-abundance.Design_6.doc, chinook-dams-lc-hatchery_proportion.Design_5.doc
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Prior to 2002 hatchery fish could not be distinguished from natural origin fish and were all passed above North Fork Dam.  The average of the hatchery proportion observed arriving at the dam in 2002 and 2003 has been applied to counts from 1974 to 2001. After 2002 marked fish were excluded above the dam, however a small proportion of hatchery fish are missed during marking. This proportion is determined by analyzing otolith marks from carcasses observed on the spawning grounds.
COMMENTS: Count at North Fork Dam / 0.78.  There were no measurements of hatchery/wild proportions until 2002.

COMMENTS: Sample size for pHOS calculation (number of live & dead steelhead with known fin-mark status) is < 10.  Small sample sizes can result in erratic results across years, and should be used with caution. Annual weather, stream flow, and other factors can result in particularly difficult (2011 & 2012) or conducive (2013) survey conditions.  These unusual survey conditions change the probability of observing the redds actually present and thus change the ratio of fish per redd observed.  This could result in an under (2011 & 2012) or over (2013) estimate of fish, based on the avg. fish per redd factor.

CONTACTAGENCY: Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife
PROTMETHNAME: Lower Columbia River Conservation and Recovery Plan for Oregon Populations of Salmon and Steelhead, chinook-dams-lc-adult-abundance.Design_6.doc, chinook-dams-lc-hatchery_proportion.Design_5.doc
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Prior to 2002 hatchery fish could not be distinguished from natural origin fish and were all passed above North Fork Dam.  The average of the hatchery proportion observed arriving at the dam in 2002 and 2003 has been applied to counts from 1974 to 2001. After 2002 marked fish were excluded above the dam, however a small proportion of hatchery fish are missed during marking. This proportion is determined by analyzing otolith marks from carcasses observed on the spawning grounds.
COMMENTS: Count at North Fork Dam / 0.78.  There were no measurements of hatchery/wild proportions until 2002.

PROTMETHNAME: Assessment of Western Oregon Adult Winter Steelhead and Lamprey  Redd Surveys 2015
COMMENTS: Annual weather, stream flow, and other factors can result in particularly difficult (2011 & 2012) or conducive (2013) survey conditions. CONTACTAGENCY: Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife
PROTMETHNAME: Lower Columbia River Conservation and Recovery Plan for Oregon Populations of Salmon and Steelhead, chinook-dams-lc-adult-abundance.Design_6.doc, chinook-dams-lc-hatchery_proportion.Design_5.doc
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Prior to 2002 hatchery fish could not be distinguished from natural origin fish and were all passed above North Fork Dam.  The average of the hatchery proportion observed arriving at the dam in 2002 and 2003 has been applied to counts from 1974 to 2001. After 2002 marked fish were excluded above the dam, however a small proportion of hatchery fish are missed during marking. This proportion is determined by analyzing otolith marks from carcasses observed on the spawning grounds.
COMMENTS: Count at North Fork Dam / 0.78.  There were no measurements of hatchery/wild proportions until 2002.
METACOMMENTS: Dam counts are located at the URL indicated in the MeasureLocation field. Consult the contact person for data regarding the remaining measures.

PROTMETHNAME: Total Natural Spawners: Estimated spawners based on expanded redd counts from the U.S. Forest Service boundary to Lick Creek on the North Fork Asotin Creek made over 1-2 days during the presumed peak of spawning season. Assumes 2.2 fish per redd, unknown mix of hatchery and wild fish each year.
COMMENTS: No Age data available due to limited return.

CONTACTAGENCY: Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife
PROTMETHNAME: Total Natural Spawners: Estimated spawners based on expanded redd counts from the U.S. Forest Service boundary to Lick Creek on the North Fork Asotin Creek made over 1-2 days during the presumed peak of spawning season. Assumes 2.2 fish per redd, unknown mix of hatchery and wild fish each year.
COMMENTS: No Age data available due to limited return.

CONTACTAGENCY: Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife
PROTMETHNAME: Estimated spawners based on expanded redd counts in the 1984-2000 index area, and in the mainstem of Asotin Creek from Lick Creek on the North Fork Asotin Creek to Headgate Dam made over 1-2 days during the presumed peak of spawning season. Assumes 2.2 fish per redd, unknown mix of hatchery and wild fish each year.

METHODADJUSTMENTS: Fish per redd expansion

Redd, live fish, and carcass counts are located at the URL indicated in the MeasureLocation field. Consult the contact person for other MeasureLocation data.

CONTACTAGENCY: Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife
PROTMETHNAME: chinook-dams-lc-adult-abundance.Design_6.doc, chinook-dams-lc-hatchery_proportion.Design_5.doc
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Prior to 2002 hatchery fish could not be distinguished from natural origin fish and were all passed above North Fork Dam.  The average of the hatchery proportion observed arriving at the dam in 2002 and 2003 has been applied to counts from 1974 to 2001. After 2002 marked fish were excluded above the dam, however a small proportion of hatchery fish are missed during marking. This proportion is determined by analyzing otolith marks from carcasses observed on the spawning grounds.
COMMENTS: Count at North Fork Dam / 0.78 and adjusted for unmarked hatchery-origin fish.  Includes Fall Creek.
METACOMMENTS: Dam counts are located at the URL indicated in the MeasureLocation field. Consult the contact person for data regarding the remaining measures.

CONTACTAGENCY: Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife
PROTMETHNAME: Viable Salmonid Population Abundance and Productivity Field and Analysis Methods for Natural Origin summer Steelhead populations in the Snake River Summer Steelhead DPS of Northeast Oregon from 1950-2015
METHODADJUSTMENTS: PIT-tag detections of smolt returns
COMMENTS:
Video chute, weir, and access to weir trap were destroyed mid-season, which prevented an abundance estimate from these methods.
Based on returning adult steelhead thate were previously PIT tagged as smolt, applying PIT array efficiency and a correction factor of 1.46. pHOS determined from observations above weir and from video monitoring. Age derived from scales collected from wild fish at the Fifteenmile Creek Weir, but sample size too small to capture true age ratio.
METACOMMENTS: ODFW reserves the right to review and revise data as needed. Consult the contact person for metric, and measure data.

CONTACTAGENCY: Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife
PROTMETHNAME: Viable Salmonid Population Abundance and Productivity Field and Analysis Methods for Natural Origin summer Steelhead populations in the Snake River Summer Steelhead DPS of Northeast Oregon from 1950-2015
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Multi Pass GRTS SGS Redd Expansion
COMMENTS: pHOS estimated from capture of hatchery returns at CTUIR weirs on Catherine Creek, Lookingglass Creek, and the Upper Grande Ronde River. Age proportion developed from scale ages from steelhead captured at three CTUIR weirs
MEASURELOCATION: Redd count data can be found at www.streamnet.org/data
METACOMMENTS: ODFW reserves the right to review and revise data as needed. Consult the contact person for metric, and measure data.

CONTACTAGENCY: Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife
PROTMETHNAME: Viable Salmonid Population Abundance and Productivity Field and Analysis Methods for Natural Origin summer Steelhead populations in the Snake River Summer Steelhead DPS of Northeast Oregon from 1950-2015
METHODADJUSTMENTS: Multi Pass GRTS SGS Redd Expansion
COMMENTS: Hatchery proportions calculated using 5-year running totals (i.e. each year bracketed by two years on either side when data available), from trapping and seining activities in the Upper John Day Basin and live and dead fish observed during GRTS and Index surveys on the upper John Day Basin. Age proportions are derived from juveniles aged using scales of spring migrants captured in rotary screw traps and PIT tag data from adults captured at Columbia River Dams.
MEASURELOCATION: Redd count data for survyes can be found at www.streamnet.org/data
METACOMMENTS: ODFW reserves the right to review and revise data as needed. Consult the contact person for metric, and measure data.

Use Minam 2015 as a "surrogate"
